lcInstruction.p: DITA uses several elements for inline styling, or styling of pieces of text inside a paragraph:

Because these inline elements are closely linked with the appearance of text, it is easy to misuse them and defeat the purpose of separating content from formatting. In many cases, it is better to use semantically rich alternatives to these elements instead, such as <term>, <cite>, or <varname>.

p.draft-comment: ok, so if we think these elements are bad, why are we provide them as examples? Why not use the "better" elements? If the answer is that b, i, u, etc are familiar and easier, I think that's reasonable, but that explanation needs to be included here.

step.info: By adding the <b> element to this paragraph, you have made the words "round-the-clock access" bold. By adding the <i> element, you have made the words "food" and "water" italic. By adding the <u> element, you have underlined the words "two weeks."TEchnically, that is not true. It's totally possible to output the <b> elements as something other than boldface. I think you need something like "The <b> element indicates that the words "round-the-clock-access" should be rendered in boldface.

Although these inline elements add emphasis to important words, they have no other semantic value. Suppose you wanted to define the words "round-the-clock access" later, or to style them the same way as other words describing feeding frequency. Rather than using the <b> element to tag the words simply as bold, you could use the <term> element to tag them as an important term. Again, if we hate b/i/u so much, why are we demonstrating them here?
There are similar, more semantically-rich alternatives for the <i> and <u> elements, as well.
